Award.AwardTitle: U.S. - Thailand Collaboration: Geologic Records of Tropical Cyclone Strikes on the Gulf of Thailand Coast.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is a US-Thailand collaborative study with the objective of establishing long-term records of tropical cyclone strikes for the Gulf of Thailand coast. The devastating impact of Hurricane Katrina in the U.S. highlighted the need for a better understanding of tropical cyclone risk and impacts for vulnerable coastlines around the world. In Thailand, historical records of tropical cyclone strikes are short, extending back only 50 or 60 years. The study will employ the new science of paleotempestology (study of ancient storms) to obtain much longer prehistorical records derived from geologic and biologic proxies of tropical cyclone strikes. Currently, very little paleotempestological research has been conducted in this region, even though this coastline is subject to intense tropical cyclone strikes, including the 1989 Category 3 Typhoon Gay ? one of the deadliest tropical cyclones in Thailand?s history, generating 11-m-high swells and causing 800 fatalities in and around the Gulf of Thailand. Field sites have already been selected in preliminary field reconnaissance conducted jointly by researchers from the University of North Texas and Chulalongkorn University. The methods employed will be a combination of trenching and coring of coastal marshes, with the aim of identifying and dating anomalous sand beds that record prehistoric tropical cyclone washover deposits. These deposits will be identified based on sediment texture, organic content, stratigraphy and marine microfossils.
The proposed project has important societal benefits because development of long-term records of tropical cyclone strikes improves assessment of recurrence intervals of large, damaging typhoons, such as Typhoon Gay. This project will catalyze future research collaborations between the U.S. and Thailand by representing a first step towards a regional database of paleotempestological records for Southeast Asia, and by integrating research and education, through participation of Chulalongkorn and UNT students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had four major goals:
1. Establish a new collaborative relationship with Prof. Montri Choowong of Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand, focusing on paleotempestology research in Thailand.
2. Conduct a paleotempestology study with Prof. Choowong at two sites on the Gulf of Thailand coast, with the objective of identifying and dating geologic records of prehistoric typhoon strikes.
3. Include Thai and U.S. graduate students in the collaborative research.
4. Collect preliminary data for inclusion in a follow-up proposal to NSF, with the objective of expanding paleotempestology research in Thailand.
     Professor Harry Williams (UNT) and a UNT graduate student, Mr. Eric Simon, spend three weeks in Thailand in June, 2013. The U.S. researchers met with Prof. Choowong and three Chulalongkorn graduate student research assistants. Two days were spent discussing the research plan and training the graduate students on the operation of field equipment (motorized coring equipment). The 6-member research team then spent 15 days in the field working at two sites – near Cha’am and Kui Buri, along the Gulf of Thailand coast (Figure 1).
    Eight sediment cores, up to 2 m long, were obtained from the coastal marsh site near Cha’am. Four cores, up to 2.1 m long, were obtained from a beach ridge plain near Kui Buri. There is strong evidence at both sites of typhoon strikes in the form of anomalous sand beds presumably deposited by typhoon storm surges (Figure 2). At Cha’am, 11 typhoon strikes are recorded over 8,800 years; near Kui Buri, 8 typhoon strikes are recorded over 7,900 years.
    This is the first successful paleotempestology study to be conducted in Thailand. A significant finding is preliminary evidence of heightened tropical cyclone activity in the mid-Holocene, possibly resulting from climate changes in the mid-Holocene Warm Period (Figure 3). This study served as a proof of concept for the methodology employed; Profs. Williams and Choowong now plan to use the same approach to expand paleotempestology research in Thailand. 
    A draft manuscript, for the journal Marine Geology, has been completed and is under review. Profs. Williams and Choowong are working on a follow-up research proposal to NSF's Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change to further investigate mid-Holocene tropical cyclone-climate linkages in the Gulf of Thailand. One of the Thai research assistants (Dr. Sumet Phantuwongraj) is now a lecturer at Chulalongkorn University, working on tropical cyclone geology. Another of the Thai research assistants (Mr. Peerasit Surakietchai) recently started his doctoral research on a paleotempestology-related study in Thailand using techniques and equipment gained from this project.
     In addition to an anticipated journal article, the project findings have been disseminated by two conference presentations:
Williams, H.F.L. 2015. Geologic Records of Holocene Typhoon Strikes on the Gulf of Thailand Coast. 5th International Summit on Climate Change and Hurricanes. June 9-14, Chania, Crete, Greece.
Williams, H.F.L. 2015. Geologic Records of Holocene Typhoon Strikes on the Gulf of Thailand Coast. Association of American Geographers, Annual Meeting, Chicago, IL, April 21-25, 2015.
